content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

In Julia, we can override the default behavior of printing an object by defining a method called `show`. Here is how you could do it:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits 
    value::Float64
    unit::String 
end

function Base.show(io::IO, f::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, f.value, " ", f.unit)
end
```
This `show` method takes in an I/O stream (`io`) and the object to be printed (`f`), and it prints out the value of the `FloatWithUnits` struct followed by a space and then the unit string. This will print out the value and unit like "1.8 meters".
